segment.source: Learn how to launch an app from another app and exchange data between the two.
segment.target: Learn how to launch an app from another app and exchange data between the two.

segment.source: This is called launching an app for results.
segment.target: This is called launching an app for results.

segment.source: Launch an app for results
segment.target: Launch an app for results

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: LaunchUriForResultsAsync
segment.target: LaunchUriForResultsAsync

segment.source: ValueSet
segment.target: ValueSet

segment.source: Learn how to launch an app from another app and exchange data between the two.
segment.target: Learn how to launch an app from another app and exchange data between the two.

segment.source: This is called launching an app for results.
segment.target: This is called launching an app for results.

segment.source: The example here shows you how to use LaunchUriForResultsAsync to launch an app for results.
segment.target: The example here shows you how to use LaunchUriForResultsAsync to launch an app for results.

segment.source: New app-to-app communication APIs in Windows 10 make it possible for Windows apps (and Windows Web apps) to launch an app and exchange data and files.
segment.target: New app-to-app communication APIs in Windows 10 make it possible for Windows apps (and Windows Web apps) to launch an app and exchange data and files.

segment.source: This enables you to build mash-up solutions from multiple apps.
segment.target: This enables you to build mash-up solutions from multiple apps.

segment.source: Using these new APIs, complex tasks that would have required the user to use multiple apps can now be handled seamlessly.
segment.target: Using these new APIs, complex tasks that would have required the user to use multiple apps can now be handled seamlessly.

segment.source: For example, your app could launch a social networking app to choose a contact, or launch a checkout app to complete a payment process.
segment.target: For example, your app could launch a social networking app to choose a contact, or launch a checkout app to complete a payment process.

segment.source: The app that you'll launch for results will be referred to as the launched app.
segment.target: The app that you'll launch for results will be referred to as the launched app.

segment.source: The app that launches the app will be referred to as the calling app.
segment.target: The app that launches the app will be referred to as the calling app.

segment.source: For this example you will write both the calling app and the launched app.
segment.target: For this example you will write both the calling app and the launched app.

segment.source: Step 1: Register the protocol to be handled in the app that you'll launch for results
segment.target: Step 1: Register the protocol to be handled in the app that you'll launch for results

segment.source: In the Package.appxmanifest file of the launched app, add a protocol extension to the Application section.
segment.target: In the Package.appxmanifest file of the launched app, add a protocol extension to the Application section.

segment.source: The example here uses a fictional protocol named test-app2app.
segment.target: The example here uses a fictional protocol named test-app2app.

segment.source: The ReturnResults attribute in the protocol extension accepts one of these values:
segment.target: The ReturnResults attribute in the protocol extension accepts one of these values:

segment.source: optional—The app can be launched for results by using the LaunchUriForResultsAsync method, or not for results by using LaunchUriAsync.
segment.target: optional—The app can be launched for results by using the LaunchUriForResultsAsync method, or not for results by using LaunchUriAsync.

segment.source: When you use optional, the launched app must determine whether it was launched for results.
segment.target: When you use optional, the launched app must determine whether it was launched for results.

segment.source: It can do that by checking the OnActivated event argument.
segment.target: It can do that by checking the OnActivated event argument.

segment.source: If the argument's IActivatedEventArgs.Kind property returns ActivationKind.ProtocolForResults, or if the type of the event argument is ProtocolActivatedEventArgs, the app was launched via LaunchUriForResultsAsync.
segment.target: If the argument's IActivatedEventArgs.Kind property returns ActivationKind.ProtocolForResults, or if the type of the event argument is ProtocolActivatedEventArgs, the app was launched via LaunchUriForResultsAsync.

segment.source: always—The app can be launched only for results; that is, it can respond only to LaunchUriForResultsAsync.
segment.target: always—The app can be launched only for results; that is, it can respond only to LaunchUriForResultsAsync.

segment.source: none—The app cannot be launched for results; it can respond only to LaunchUriAsync.
segment.target: none—The app cannot be launched for results; it can respond only to LaunchUriAsync.

segment.source: In this protocol-extension example, the app can be launched only for results.
segment.target: In this protocol-extension example, the app can be launched only for results.

segment.source: This simplifies the logic inside the OnActivated method, discussed below, because we have to handle only the "launched for results" case and not the other ways that the app could be activated.
segment.target: This simplifies the logic inside the OnActivated method, discussed below, because we have to handle only the "launched for results" case and not the other ways that the app could be activated.

segment.source: Step 2: Override Application.OnActivated in the app that you'll launch for results
segment.target: Step 2: Override Application.OnActivated in the app that you'll launch for results

segment.source: If this method does not already exist in the launched app, create it within the class defined in App.xaml.cs.
segment.target: If this method does not already exist in the launched app, create it within the class defined in App.xaml.cs.

segment.source: In an app that lets you pick your friends in a social network, this function could be where you open the people-picker page.
segment.target: In an app that lets you pick your friends in a social network, this function could be where you open the people-picker page.

segment.source: In this next example, a page named LaunchedForResultsPage is displayed when the app is activated for results.
segment.target: In this next example, a page named LaunchedForResultsPage is displayed when the app is activated for results.

segment.source: Ensure that the using statement is included at the top of the file.
segment.target: Ensure that the using statement is included at the top of the file.

segment.source: Because the protocol extension in the Package.appxmanifest file specifies ReturnResults as always, the code just shown can cast directly to ProtocolForResultsActivatedEventArgs with confidence that only ProtocolForResultsActivatedEventArgs will be sent to OnActivated for this app.
segment.target: Because the protocol extension in the Package.appxmanifest file specifies ReturnResults as always, the code just shown can cast directly to ProtocolForResultsActivatedEventArgs with confidence that only ProtocolForResultsActivatedEventArgs will be sent to OnActivated for this app.

segment.source: If your app can be activated in ways other than launching for results, you can check whether IActivatedEventArgs.Kind property returns ActivationKind.ProtocolForResults to tell whether the app was launched for results.
segment.target: If your app can be activated in ways other than launching for results, you can check whether IActivatedEventArgs.Kind property returns ActivationKind.ProtocolForResults to tell whether the app was launched for results.

segment.source: Step 3: Add a ProtocolForResultsOperation field to the app you launch for results
segment.target: Step 3: Add a ProtocolForResultsOperation field to the app you launch for results

segment.source: You'll use the ProtocolForResultsOperation field to signal when the launched app is ready to return the result to the calling app.
segment.target: You'll use the ProtocolForResultsOperation field to signal when the launched app is ready to return the result to the calling app.

segment.source: In this example, the field is added to the LaunchedForResultsPage class because you'll complete the launch-for-results operation from that page and will need access to it.
segment.target: In this example, the field is added to the LaunchedForResultsPage class because you'll complete the launch-for-results operation from that page and will need access to it.

segment.source: Step 4: Override OnNavigatedTo() in the app you launch for results
segment.target: Step 4: Override OnNavigatedTo() in the app you launch for results

segment.source: Override the OnNavigatedTo method on the page that you'll display when your app is launched for results.
segment.target: Override the OnNavigatedTo method on the page that you'll display when your app is launched for results.

segment.source: If this method does not already exist, create it within the class for the page defined in pagename.xaml.cs.
segment.target: If this method does not already exist, create it within the class for the page defined in pagename.xaml.cs.

segment.source: Ensure that the following using statement is included at the top of the file:
segment.target: Ensure that the following using statement is included at the top of the file:

segment.source: The NavigationEventArgs object in the OnNavigatedTo method contains the data passed from the calling app.
segment.target: The NavigationEventArgs object in the OnNavigatedTo method contains the data passed from the calling app.

segment.source: The data may not exceed 100KB and is stored in a ValueSet object.
segment.target: The data may not exceed 100KB and is stored in a ValueSet object.

segment.source: In this example code, the launched app expects the data sent from the calling app to be in a ValueSet under a key named TestData, because that's what the example's calling app is coded to send.
segment.target: In this example code, the launched app expects the data sent from the calling app to be in a ValueSet under a key named TestData, because that's what the example's calling app is coded to send.

segment.source: Step 5: Write code to return data to the calling app
segment.target: Step 5: Write code to return data to the calling app

segment.source: In the launched app, use ProtocolForResultsOperation to return data to the calling app.
segment.target: In the launched app, use ProtocolForResultsOperation to return data to the calling app.

segment.source: In this example code, a ValueSet object is created that contains the value to return to the calling app.
segment.target: In this example code, a ValueSet object is created that contains the value to return to the calling app.

segment.source: The ProtocolForResultsOperation field is then used to send the value to the calling app.
segment.target: The ProtocolForResultsOperation field is then used to send the value to the calling app.

segment.source: Step 6: Write code to launch the app for results and get the returned data
segment.target: Step 6: Write code to launch the app for results and get the returned data

segment.source: Launch the app from within an async method in your calling app as shown in this example code.
segment.target: Launch the app from within an async method in your calling app as shown in this example code.

segment.source: Note the using statements, which are necessary for the code to compile:
segment.target: Note the using statements, which are necessary for the code to compile:

segment.source: In this example, a ValueSet containing the key TestData is passed to the launched app.
segment.target: In this example, a ValueSet containing the key TestData is passed to the launched app.

segment.source: The launched app creates a ValueSet with a key named ReturnedData that contains the result returned to the caller.
segment.target: The launched app creates a ValueSet with a key named ReturnedData that contains the result returned to the caller.

segment.source: You must build and deploy the app that you'll launch for results before running your calling app.
segment.target: You must build and deploy the app that you'll launch for results before running your calling app.

segment.source: Otherwise, LaunchUriResult.Status will report LaunchUriStatus.AppUnavailable.
segment.target: Otherwise, LaunchUriResult.Status will report LaunchUriStatus.AppUnavailable.

segment.source: You'll need the family name of the launched app when you set the TargetApplicationPackageFamilyName.
segment.target: You'll need the family name of the launched app when you set the TargetApplicationPackageFamilyName.

segment.source: One way to get the family name is to make the following call from within the launched app:
segment.target: One way to get the family name is to make the following call from within the launched app:

segment.source: Remarks
segment.target: Remarks

segment.source: The example in this how-to provides a "hello world" introduction to launching an app for results.
segment.target: The example in this how-to provides a "hello world" introduction to launching an app for results.

segment.source: The key things to note are that the new LaunchUriForResultsAsync API lets you asynchronously launch an app and communicate via the ValueSet class.
segment.target: The key things to note are that the new LaunchUriForResultsAsync API lets you asynchronously launch an app and communicate via the ValueSet class.

segment.source: Passing data via a ValueSet is limited to 100KB.
segment.target: Passing data via a ValueSet is limited to 100KB.

segment.source: If you need to pass larger amounts of data, you can share files by using the SharedStorageAccessManager class to create file tokens that you can pass between apps.
segment.target: If you need to pass larger amounts of data, you can share files by using the SharedStorageAccessManager class to create file tokens that you can pass between apps.

segment.source: For example, given a ValueSet named , you could store the token to a file that you want to share with the launched app:
segment.target: For example, given a ValueSet named , you could store the token to a file that you want to share with the launched app:

segment.source: Then pass it to the launched app via LaunchUriForResultsAsync.
segment.target: Then pass it to the launched app via LaunchUriForResultsAsync.
